prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so I need to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. Let me break down the situation.

The author is a friend who's had a conversation with another friend who's been going through a lot with five kids from different fathers and is now divorced. The friend has been making insulting comments about the author's weight, dating life, and job. The author tried to brush it off for two years but finally responded by pointing out the friend's situation as the reason she's having trouble finding someone. The friend got angry, and now mutual friends are criticizing the author for being privileged and a bad friend.

First, the author's friend has been making personal and possibly hurtful comments. The author felt insulted and tired of it. The response the author gave was about the friend's situation—five kids with different dads and no child support. The author thought this was the truth and a valid reason why someone might be hesitant to date her.

But the mutual friends are saying the author is wrong, pointing to "skinny privilege" and entitlement. The author argues that they've worked hard for their achievements.

So, is the author in the wrong? Well, the key points are whether the author's response was appropriate given the context. The author was defending themselves after two years of being insulted. However, bringing up such a personal and sensitive issue about someone else's family might be seen as crossing a line, even if it's the truth. The friend's actions (five different fathers) could indeed make it harder to find a partner, but pointing that out in the heat of the moment might come off as judgmental or harsh, especially if the friend is already vulnerable.

The author might have thought they were giving honest feedback, but the way it was delivered could be seen as attacking the friend's personal life rather than addressing the insults directly. The friend's response (insult fury and hanging up) suggests that the comment was hurtful. The mutual friends' reactions also indicate that the community perceives the author's response as unkind or insensitive.

However, considering that the author was being insulted repeatedly and finally stood up for themselves, there's a case to be made that they had a right to respond. The challenge is whether the author could have addressed the friend's behavior in a more constructive way without being judgmental about her personal choices.

Alternative responses could have been to set boundaries about not engaging in the insults or discussing the friend's dating life in a supportive way. But the author chose to directly address the issue by pointing out the friend's situation, which might not be the best approach in a friendship where the friend is already feeling vulnerable.

In conclusion, while the author's intent was to stop the insults and give honest feedback, the method of doing so by highlighting a sensitive personal matter might have been unkind and contributed to the fallout. So, the author might be in the wrong for how they responded, even if their intention was to help.
